I have repeatedly examined the heterogeneous character of the Christian Democracy on

Anyhow, De Gasperi felt that it was his duty to stay on as party secretary and do his

With De Gasperi eliminating himself, then, the choice of Scelba was virtually inevit¬
able, It was Scelba who had started the agitation for a reconstruction of the four-party
government! a proposition which his party directorate had accepted, even if by a narrow
margin. There was no one else of comparable stature who had taken this line so decisively.
And from the standpoint of parliamentary protocol, it had bee Scelba*e ovara speech that

Those ar© the real reasons, then, why President Einaudl conferred the burden of forming
a new government on Scelba on February 8*
It was not, as some observers have assumed, that Einaudi felt the Italian situation
had become so shaky that the hardboiled Sicilian policeman had to be called in to push a
tough policy toward the Commu ists.
In fact, those who know Scelba best will tell you that he is a devoted democrat. They
defend his record as interior minister *nd claim that his flying squads never broke up a
peaceful, law-abiding political rally — by the Communists or anyone else.
But in those critical postwar ye- rs when the Italian political situation was touch and
go, Scelba did tfot hesitate to use the police power to the fullest to enforce the laws and
recreate respect for the authority of the government. Probably not even Scelba himself
would contend there were no police excesses in that period,
When he first took over as interior minister, Scelba asked for a report on the condi¬
tion and morale of the national police. When h© got that pessimistic report he is said to
have remarked, grimly* "If 1 were a Communist I would start the revolution tomorrow,**
The Communists mad© their most serious bid for power after the attempted assassination
of their leader, Palmiro Togli^tti, in the summer of 1948. Scelba had been interior
minister for only a year and a half.
The Communists called a general strike to protest the attempt on Togliatti, and the re¬
sponse was impressive. Then it became apparent that they intended to prolong the strike and,
if possible, to us© it as a weapon with which to bring down the government. At this point,
